title: Ishioka, Ibaraki
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Ibaraki%20Prefecture">Ibaraki Prefecture</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. , the city had an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 72,351 in 28,291 households and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 336 persons per km². The percentage of the population aged over 65 was 33.5%. The total area of the city is .
Geography.
Ishioka is located in central Ibaraki Prefecture, approximately 70 kilometers north of central Tokyo. It is bordered by Lake <a href="Lake%20Kasumigaura">Kasumigaura</a> to the south and by mountains on all other sides. The urban area of the city is in the east.
Surrounding municipalities.
Ibaraki Prefecture
Climate.
Ishioka has a <a href="Humid%20continental%20climate">Humid continental climate</a> (Köppen "Cfa") characterized by warm summers and cool winters with light snowfall. The average annual temperature in Ishioka is 13.8 °C. The average annual rainfall is 1331 mm with September as the wettest month. The temperatures are highest on average in August, at around 25.8 °C, and lowest in January, at around 2.8 °C.
Demographics.
Per Japanese census data, the population of Ishioka has remained relatively stable over the past 40 years.
History.
During the <a href="Nara%20period">Nara period</a>, the <a href="kokufu">provincial capital</a> of <a href="Hitachi%20Province">Hitachi Province</a> was located in what is now part of the city of Ishioka. The area was known as , or simply as “Fuchū” for most of history and developed as a <a href="j%C5%8Dkamachi">castle town</a> during the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a> for <a href="Hitachi-Fuch%C5%AB%20Domain">Hitachi-Fuchū Domain</a>. The <a href="han%20system">domain</a> was renamed “Ishioka Domain” in 1869. With the establishment of the modern municipalities system on April 1, 1889 after the <a href="Meiji%20restoration">Meiji restoration</a>, the town of Ishioka was created. Much of the town was destroyed in a fire of March 14, 1929.
Ishioka was raised to city status on February 11, 1954. The new city annexed the neighboring villages of Mi and Sekigawa on December 1, 1954. On October 1, 2005, the town of <a href="Yasato%2C%20Ibaraki">Yasato</a> (from <a href="Niihari%20District%2C%20Ibaraki">Niihari District</a>) was merged into Ishioka.
Government.
Ishioka has a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government with a directly elected mayor and a <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> city council of 22 members. Ishioka contributes two members to the Ibaraki Prefectural Assembly. In terms of national politics, the city is part of <a href="Ibaraki%201st%20district">Ibaraki 1st district</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Representatives%20of%20Japan">lower house</a> of the <a href="Diet%20of%20Japan">Diet of Japan</a>.
Economy.
Ishioka has a diverse economy. Agriculture includes <a href="lotus%20root">lotus root</a>s, which are cultivated around Lake Kasumigaura, <a href="tobacco">tobacco</a>, and horticulture such as persimmons, <a href="mandarin%20orange">mandarin orange</a>s, and strawberries cultivated at the foot of <a href="Mount%20Tsukuba">Mount Tsukuba</a>. In addition, the countryside is one of the leading <a href="paddy%20field">rice areas</a> in Ibaraki prefecture. Pig farming and chicken farming and dairy farming are also major agricultural contributors. The city has an <a href="industrial%20park">industrial park</a>, with factories owned by Panasonic and Toyo Seikan, among others. "<a href="Sake">Sake</a>" brewing is a traditional local industry, as is the manufacturing of incense sticks.
Education.
Ishioka has 19 public elementary schools and eight public middle schools operated by the city government, and three public high schools operated by the Ibaraki Prefectural Board of Education. There is also one private middle school and one private high school.
Transportation.
Railway.
 <a href="JR%20East">JR East</a> – <a href="J%C5%8Dban%20Line">Jōban Line</a>
